references: LwPosr is compared to existing methods (with both lightweight and heavier techniques) for HPE on open-source benchmark datasets. Table 1 and 2 illustrate the comparison of the number of parameters and MAE for the compared frameworks. They are as follows. (1) 3DDFA¬†[54] uses a cascaded CNN network which tends to fit 3D model to a single image. It is described to perform well on occlusions. (2) KEPLER¬†[22] uses Heatmap-CNN to understand the local and global features to detect keypoints for face alignment and HPE is a by-product task. (3) Dlib¬†[20] is a standard well used library for faces for applications of HPE, face detection, keypoints prediction. (4) FAN¬†[4] utilizes landmark localization network combined with residual block forming a multi-stage network with multi-scale features. (5) Hopenet¬†[30] is ResNet based fine-grained structure using classification and regression loss. (6) Shao ¬†[32] works on the adjustment of margins of detected bounding box for faces using a CNN architecture. (7) SSR-Net-MD¬†[48] uses soft stage-wise regression. (8) FSA-Caps-Fusion¬†[46] learns feature aggregation for fine-grained regression. (9) TriNet¬†[6] uses ResNet along with feaure agregagtion as used in ¬†[46] for three different streams. It is a memory intensive network. (10) WHENet [53] is also one of the low memory networks (having 4.4√ó1064.4superscript1064.4\times 10^{6} number of parameters) which uses efficientNet (lightweight backbone) and uses multi loss (classification and regression loss). (11) VGG16¬†[17] and VGG16+RNN¬†[17] are highly memory expensive models with CNN and CNN with RNN respectively, using Bayesian filters analysis. (12) DeepHeadPose¬†[25] uses depth images (low resolution) and uses regression and classification for each angle prediction. (13) Martin¬†[24] too uses depth images and performs registration to a 3D head model.

Protocol PùüèsubscriptùëÉ1\boldsymbol{P_{1}}: To our best knowledge, LwPosr is the lowest memory requiring network with just 0.159√ó1060.159superscript1060.159\times 10^{6} parameters. TriNet has lowest MAE on AFLW2000 dataset with a difference of 0.68 on MAE but it has ‚àº163.5similar-toabsent163.5\sim 163.5 times more number of parameters. WHENet has least MAE on BIWI dataset with a difference of 0.24 but it requires 27.727.727.7 times more number of parameters than LwPosr. In the literature, SSR-Net-MD has the least number of parameters in the network. LwPosr has outperformed it on MAE on both the datasets by 0.6 on BIWI and 0.66 on AFLW2000 dataset simultaneously reducing the number of parameters. Hence, LwPosr has significantly improved the benchmark for networks with least number of parameters for HPE to our best knowledge and as is also evident in Table 1. LwPosr Œ±ùõº\alpha has performed better than LwPosr on AFLW2000 dataset. The only difference is that LwPosr Œ±ùõº\alpha uses Gelu activation function in transformer encoders instead of Relu.

references: LwPosr is compared to existing methods (with both lightweight and heavier techniques) for HPE on open-source benchmark datasets. Table 1 and 2 illustrate the comparison of the number of parameters and MAE for the compared frameworks. They are as follows. (1) 3DDFA¬†[54] uses a cascaded CNN network which tends to fit 3D model to a single image. It is described to perform well on occlusions. (2) KEPLER¬†[22] uses Heatmap-CNN to understand the local and global features to detect keypoints for face alignment and HPE is a by-product task. (3) Dlib¬†[20] is a standard well used library for faces for applications of HPE, face detection, keypoints prediction. (4) FAN¬†[4] utilizes landmark localization network combined with residual block forming a multi-stage network with multi-scale features. (5) Hopenet¬†[30] is ResNet based fine-grained structure using classification and regression loss. (6) Shao ¬†[32] works on the adjustment of margins of detected bounding box for faces using a CNN architecture. (7) SSR-Net-MD¬†[48] uses soft stage-wise regression. (8) FSA-Caps-Fusion¬†[46] learns feature aggregation for fine-grained regression. (9) TriNet¬†[6] uses ResNet along with feaure agregagtion as used in ¬†[46] for three different streams. It is a memory intensive network. (10) WHENet [53] is also one of the low memory networks (having 4.4√ó1064.4superscript1064.4\times 10^{6} number of parameters) which uses efficientNet (lightweight backbone) and uses multi loss (classification and regression loss). (11) VGG16¬†[17] and VGG16+RNN¬†[17] are highly memory expensive models with CNN and CNN with RNN respectively, using Bayesian filters analysis. (12) DeepHeadPose¬†[25] uses depth images (low resolution) and uses regression and classification for each angle prediction. (13) Martin¬†[24] too uses depth images and performs registration to a 3D head model.

Protocol PùüêsubscriptùëÉ2\boldsymbol{P_{2}}: It is evident from Table 2 that LwPosr has the least number of parameters compared to all other networks in this protocol (to our best knowledge). It has improved the performance over SSR-Net-MD (previous benchmark for least number of parameters) by 0.25 on MAE. TriNet performs quite efficiently on P2subscriptùëÉ2P_{2} but it has ‚àº163.5similar-toabsent163.5\sim 163.5 times more parameters (‚àº26√ó106similar-toabsent26superscript106\sim 26\times 10^{6} as compared to 0.159√ó1060.159superscript1060.159\times 10^{6}). VGG16 and VGG16+RNN has 870 times more number of parameters than LwPosr. Thus, even though these networks have slightly better performance than LwPosr on P2subscriptùëÉ2P_{2}, these are difficult to be used on small mobile devices.

references: All the results corresponding to ablations performed using Protocol P1subscriptùëÉ1P_{1} are concisely described in Table 3 (parameter being studied is varied and other parameters are kept constant to 3 encoder layers, 4 heads, relu activation function, sine embedding, 0.001 learning rate, [0.5,0.5,2]/30.50.523[0.5,0.5,2]/3 weights in the weighted mean, MAE loss, 3 stages).

Learning Rate: Initial learning rates are investigated for values of 0.01, 0.001, 0.0001. It is evident from Table 3 that training gets stuck in local mimina with the learning rate of 0.01. The learning rate of 0.001 performs better than the other two.

We implemented 4 stages in LwPosr, where Q=4ùëÑ4Q=4 instead of Q=3ùëÑ3Q=3 (as mentioned in section 3). Table¬†3 illustrates the number of parameters and results for the corresponding stages. It shows that increasing the stages increases the number of parameters which have to be learnt. Hence, the network size increases. The quantitative results on average do not change. So, network with three stages is more optimized in terms of number of parameters and evaluation results.
